School of Rare Earths, University of Science and Technology of China Ganzhou 341000 PR China A series of Mg3Al1−xCexO composite oxide catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation for the transesterification of ethylene glycol to ethylene carbonate. The characterization results revealed that the addition of cerium changed the acid-base properties of the catalyst and that the strong basic sites on the catalyst surface played an important role in the reaction. The Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O catalyst showed the highest catalytic activity (ethylene carbonate yield 98.1%). Compared with pure Mg-Al oxide, the appropriate addition of Ce was conducive to improving the surface basicity and adsorbed oxygen content of the catalyst. Additionally, the reaction process of the formation of ethylene glycol hydroxyl group with the alkoxy anion formed by the catalyst attacking the carbonyl carbon of nucleophilic dimethyl carbonate to form an adsorption intermediate (HEMC) on the catalyst surface for further intramolecular rearrangement to form ethylene carbonate was confirmed by operando infrared spectroscopy. The reaction kinetics shows that the reaction conforms to the second-order kinetic equation, and the activation energy is 53.71 kJ·mol−1. Catalytic stability in a fixed-bed reactor was studied. After a long cycle of use (150 h), the yield of ethylene carbonate was stabilized at about 89.0%. Graphical Abstract Using ethylene glycol and dimethyl carbonate as the representative raw materials, ethylene carbonate was synthesized efficiently under mild conditions. ga1 Keywords Vicinal diols Cyclic carbonate Transesterification Mg3Al1−xCexO Acid-base Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Cyclic carbonates have unique chemical properties such as high dielectric constant and high boiling point. They are often used as electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries, as well as nonpolar proton solvent, polyurethane and polycarbonate monomer [1,2]. Ethylene carbonate is a kind of heterocyclic ketone with high stability, high boiling point, and low toxicity. It is not only an excellent benign polar organic solvent that could replace traditional harmful polar aprotic solvents, such as dimethylformamide, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, and acetonitrile [3], but also used as an organic intermediate and is widely used in polymer synthesis, gas separation, electrochemistry and so on [4,5]. Ethylene glycol is an important and cheap petrochemical raw material, which can be obtained from coal-to-ethylene glycol (CTEG). In recent years, with the rapid development of the coal chemical industry, the production of CTEG has increased rapidly. Furthermore, with the improvement of research technology, ethylene glycol can also be generated from cellulose or others biomass [6,7]. It has become a hot topic to consider how to convert a large amount of low-purity and cheap ethylene glycol into high-value chemicals. With the improvement of production technology, the reaction route to prepare linear carbonate from cyclic carbonate has gradually reached saturation. Taking this as an inspiration, it was found that the reverse reaction of this route has a specfic certain economic potential, which not only can realize the efficient application of ethylene glycol, but also for the synthesis of dimethyl carbonate with carbon dioxide from the methanol produced by the reaction, achieving a green, low-carbon and high-value conversion. Therefore, it is noted that using coarse linear carbonate (dimethyl carbonate, diethyl carbonate, etc.) from coal as carbonylation reagent and ethylene glycol as raw material to synthesize ethylene carbonate is a high-quality and efficient way to realize the high-value utilization of ethylene glycol. The preparation is the earliest synthetic method of ethylene carbonate by direct phosgenation of ethylene glycol, but this method is prohibited due to the severe toxicity of phosgene and environmental pollution [8]. Carbon dioxide (CO2) can also react with ethylene glycol to prepare ethylene carbonate, but the water production limits the reaction equilibrium [9]. The coupling of ethylene oxide and CO2 to prepare cyclic carbonate is an important synthetic method, which is relatively mature at present, but still needs to develop a catalytic system with milder reaction conditions and higher safety [10]. Urea alcoholysis with urea and diol as raw materials, this route has the merits of low cost, wide range of sources, high atomic economy, but the by-product ammonia has certain toxicity and equipment corrosion, so it has partial limitations [11]. In recent years, the preparation of cyclic carbonates by transesterification of linear carbonates (e.g. dimethyl carbonate) is theoretically feasible route for the preparation of ethylene carbonate using ethylene glycol and dimethyl carbonate due to its mild conditions, high selectivity and wide range of raw material sources, in line with the green concept of chemical industry development [11,12]. Hydrotalcites (HTs) is a layered anionic functional inorganic material, which can not only obtain layered HTs with different layer spacing and special properties by exchanging interlayer anions with other anions, but also can adjust its basicity by changing the ratio of interlayer/surface anions Mg2+ and Al3+ [13–15]. Up to now, HTs have been widely used as a catalyst precursor because of their excellent structure and properties. How to improve the catalytic performance by adjusting the acid-base properties of the catalyst surface has become a hot topic. Light rare earth elements are reported to have a strong synergistic effect with HT due to their abundant 4 f empty orbitals [16]. Cerium dioxide (CeO2) can not only be used as a catalyst, but also as a carrier or modifier. The obtained CeO2 nanocomposite can not only freely switch its oxidation state while maintaining the structural integrity, but also profoundly change the reactivity of the two-phase interface. The oxygen vacancy structure of CeO2 allows it to be used in the oxidation-reduction reaction. Besides, the difference in coordination unsaturated degree of Ce4+ and O2- on the CeO2 surface leads to different acid-base properties. Therefore, the addition of CeO2 is beneficial to improve the basicity of HT [17]. CeO2 has been widely used as a heterogeneous catalyst in organic catalysis in recent years due to its unique surface and volume properties. The synergistic action of the unique acid-base bifunctional sites of CeO2 can effectively activate the surface hydroxyl group of vicinal diols and the carbonylation reagent carbonyl group, which is favorable for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. Herein, a series of different Mg3Al1−xCexO composite oxide catalysts were prepared by the co-precipitation method, and their performance in the transesterification of ethylene glycol with dimethyl carbonate to synthesize ethylene carbonate was evaluated. The phase structure, texture properties, and acid-base properties of the catalyst were investigated by XRD, BET, SEM-EDS, XPS, and CO2/NH3-TPD. Additionally, the reaction pathway and mechanism were further analyzed by operando IR spectroscopy. The effects of reaction temperature, raw material ratio, catalyst dosage, and reaction time on the synthesis of ethylene carbonate were investigated. The synthesis of ethylene carbonate was studied from the perspective of reaction kinetics, and the universality of Mg3Al1−xCexO composite oxide catalysts was discussed. Finally, the long-term stability of the catalyst was studied using a fixed-bed. Scheme 1. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Mg(NO3)2·6 H2O, Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, and Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O (99%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd, NaOH and Na2CO3 (99%), were purchased from Xilong Chemical Co, Ltd, dimethyl carbonate, ethylene glycol, 1,2-propanediol, glycerol, 1,2-butanediol, 1,3-butanediol, 2,3-butanediol, and biphenyl (99%) were purchased from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation A series of HT precursors with different Ce contents were prepared by co-precipitation with Mg(NO3)2·6 H2O, Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O as raw material. Firstly, dissolve an appropriate amount of Mg(NO3)2·6 H2O, Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, and Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O in deionized water according to the ratio of Mg2+:(Al/Ce)3+=3:1, and stir evenly as solution A, dissolve a certain amount of NaOH and Na2CO3 in 200 mL deionized water, stir evenly as solution B. The formulated alkali solution is added uniformly to solution A at a rate that holds PH in the 10–11 range. After dropping, it was agitatedly aged for 1 h and then crystallized into a 70 ℃ water bath for 24 h. After filtration, washing, and drying, put in a Muffle furnace at 5 ℃/min temperature to 500 ℃, calcined for 6 h. The composite oxide catalysts with different Ce amounts are recorded as Mg3Al1−xCexO (x = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 0.8), and Ce accounts for 0%, 2.5%, 12.5%, and 20.0% of the total molar ratio. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The phase structure and properties of the samples were characterized by XRD (scanning range 2θ of 5–90°). The average crystallite size of MgO and CeO2 in solids is calculated according to the Debye-Scheler formula. The texture properties such as specific surface area, pore volume and pore size distribution were analyzed by ASAP 2020 PLUS HD88 automatic specific surface area and micropore analyzer (BET). The morphology and surface element composition of the catalyst was analyzed by scanning electron microscope and energy dispersive spectroscopy (SEM-EDS). The morphology of the samples was analyzed with Zeiss Gemini 300 microscope under 30 kV accelerating voltage, and TF20 was used to obtain the transmission electron microscope (TEM) morphology of the catalyst. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is used to analyze the surface of the valence. The instrument model is Thermo ESCALAB 250XI, corrected by C 1 s = 284.8 eV binding energy. The acid-base of samples was measured by temperature programmed analysis (CO2/NH3-TPD). Firstly, about 100 mg of the sample was weighed and warmed up to 200 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min and cooled down to 50 °C. Subsequently, CO2/NH3 was injected for adsorption for 1 h, switched to helium and desorbed CO2/NH3 for 40 min, and finally warmed up to 800 °C until the TPD analysis was completed. Operando IR spectroscopy: Mettler Toledo React IR 15 m equipped with a 9.5 mm AgX optical fiber catheter diamond ATR probe is used for real-time monitoring. The spectrum acquisition range is 500–3000 cm−1, and the scanning interval is 15 s/time. The stability of the catalyst was tested by a fixed-bed. After the catalyst was formed by the tablet press, 1 g catalyst with a diameter of 40–60 mesh was selected and loaded into the catalyst bed. Under optimal conditions, continuous experiments were carried out for 150 h. 2.4 Catalyst activity test The transesterification reaction with ethylene glycol and dimethyl carbonate was carried out in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave under self-generated pressure. The reaction temperature was controlled by the SLM100 heating sleeve of Beijing Century Senlong Experimental Instrument Co, LTD. After the reaction, the product was separated in a high-speed centrifuge and then partially liquidated, ethanol and biphenyl were added as solvents and standard substances, respectively. It was quantitatively analyzed by gas chromatography (AOC-20I PLUS, 30 m * 0.32 mm*1 µm) with ethanol as solvent. The conversion of ethylene glycol, the selectivity, and yield of ethylene carbonate are calculated as follows: Conv . of EG = n 0 EG − n EG n 0 EG × 100 % Sel . of EC = n EC n 0 EG × Conv . of ( EG ) × 100 % Where n 0 EG represents the initial molar amount of ethylene glycol, n EG and n EC represent the molar amount of the ethylene glycol and ethylene carbonate after the reaction, respectively. (The results of the gas chromatography analysis of the by-products are shown in Supporting Information Fig. S13.). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 showed the wide-angle XRD spectra of Mg3Al1−xCexO. It was seen that only characteristic peak of MgO and CeO2 were detected in all Mg3Al1−xCexO samples, indicating that Al2O3 exist as amorphous phase. At the same time, the Mg3Al1−xCexO catalyst showed characteristic peaks of the periclase phase (MgO), which means that the basic structure of pure Mg3AlO is preserved. In addition, the Mg3Al1−xCexO catalyst showed obvious diffraction peaks of CeO2 single crystal at 2θ of 28.67°, 33.26°, 47.73°, 56.56° corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), (311) crystal plane of CeO2 (JCPDS-34–0394) [18], and the space group is Fm-3 m (225), which further confirms the cubic fluorite phase structure of CeO2 [19]. Moreover, with the increase of Ce content, the peak of CeO2 becomes stronger and sharper, and the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the catalyst decrease gradually, indicating that the crystallinity and grain size of the catalyst increase gradually. Noteworthy to say that, the peak of the (111) crystal plane is the strongest in the exposed crystal plane of CeO2. Lattice parameter a of CeO2 is related to the size of cations in brucite [20], and the calculation results are shown in Table 1. With the increase of Ce content from 2.5% to 20.0%, the lattice parameter a increased from 5.386 to 5.398 Å. This is due to compared with Al3+ (0.053 nm), Ce ions with higher ion radius (Ce3+ 0.102 nm, Ce4+ 0.087 nm) preferentially entered the interlayer structure [21]. The average particle sizes of MgO and CeO2 calculated by Scheler equation (200) and (111) are also shown in Table 1. As the Ce content increases, the average grain size of MgO and CeO2 increases from 5.7 and 6.7 nm to 12.6 and 10.3 nm, respectively, indicating that the existence of CeO2 and MgO promotes the growth of grains, and the variation of ceria grains is more obvious. Fig. 2 is the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm and the pore size distribution curve of the catalyst measured. As shown in Fig. 2(a), all the catalysts are type IV nitrogen adsorption desorption isotherms and type H3 hysteresis loops, which are the natural characteristics of mesoporous materials, indicating that the materials conform to the mesoporous structure [16]. As can be seen from Fig. 2(b), with the increase of Ce content, the pore size distribution pattern of the catalyst changed from narrow to wide, the pore structure was almost concentrated in the mesoporous range of 2–30 nm, with almost no micropores smaller than 2 nm observed, indicating that the synthesized catalyst basically matched the characteristics of mesoporous structure. Table 1 showed the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution data of catalysts with different Ce content. It can be seen that the Mg3AlO catalyst has the largest specific surface area (227.20 m2·g−1) in the absence of Ce. While adding the Ce content from 2.5% to 20.0%, the surface area of the catalyst decreased from 198.67 to 97.33 m2·g−1. This is due to the accumulation of Ce ions with large ion radius on the surface, which leads to pore blockage [13,14,22]. In addition, the pore size becomes larger with increasing Ce content, which is opposite to the trends of surface area. Table 2. Fig. 3 showed the SEM and HRTEM images of the catalyst. As can be seen from Fig. 3(a) and (b), compared with the morphology of Mg3AlO, the surface morphology of Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O prepared by co-precipitation method presents the irregular spherical or elliptical structure, indicating that the introduction of Ce has little effect on the structure of HT. HRTEM illustrated the lattice stripe of Mg3AlO and Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O, and the results are shown in Fig. (c) and (d). It is observed that, the lattice spacing of the prominent surface of Mg3AlO and Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O catalyst is 0.211 and 0.316 nm, corresponding to the (200) and (111) crystal planes of MgO and CeO2 [23], the result of which was consistent with XRD. The prepared samples were also analyzed by EDS (Fig. S1), and elements of Mg, Al, Ce, and O were found. It is clearly seen that Ce is uniformly distributed on the surface of the catalyst, and O exists in the metal oxide formed by the presence of precursor calcined [24]. The surface chemical states of Mg3Al1−xCexO were further analyzed by XPS. It is seen from Fig. 4(a) that the obvious peaks at around 1304.4 eV and 74.4 eV belonged to Mg 1 s and Al 2p. It can also observed that, compared with the peak of Mg 1 s and Al 2p in Mg3AlO, the peak of Mg 1 s and Al 2p in Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O, Mg3Al0.5Ce0.5O and Mg3Al0.2Ce0.8O shifted to higher binding energy, which is attributed to the strong interaction between pure Mg-Al HT and CeO2 [25,26]. The shoulder peaks at 529.3 and 531.7 eV are lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen in the defective oxygen of the product, respectively [27]. The O 1 s XPS spectrum is shown in Fig. 4(e). According to the distribution, the binding band of 530–531 eV is denoted as surface adsorbed oxygen (denoted as Oα), the binding energy of 529–530 eV is attributed to lattice oxygen (denoted as Oβ), and the binding energy of 531 eV and above is denoted as surface hydroxyl group. The quantitative calculation results of Oα/(Oα+Oβ) are shown in Table 4. The Oα/(Oα+Oβ) of Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O reaches 90.2%, which has the highest surface adsorption oxygen ratio, indicating that Ce species entering the MgO lattice can promote the adsorption of more oxygen atoms on the surface of Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O catalyst. Interestingly, Wu found that doping Ce into the lattice of CdO would promote the increase of adsorbed oxygen in the study of synthesis of glycerol carbonate using CeO2-CdO [28]. Adsorbed oxygen with higher mobility facilitates reaction activation and friendly adsorption of materials, improving the catalytic performance of the catalyst [29]. Ce element on the catalyst surface exists in the form of Ce3+ and Ce4+ (Fig. 4c), in which 915.9, 906.9, 900.2, 897.6, 888.0, 881.7 eV belongs to Ce4+ and 901.8, 883.9 eV belongs to Ce3+, respectively. Table 3 calculated the Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) ratio of catalysts. The results show that the order of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) is Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O > Mg3Al0.5Ce0.5O > Mg3Al0.2Ce0.8O, indicating that Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O has the highest number of oxygen vacancies. This result also showed that the interaction between CeO2 and Mg-Al oxide is the strongest of Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O, which is consistent with the previous reports [30]. While with the increase of Ce content from 2.5% to 20.0%, the proportion of Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) decreases from 17.4% to 7.4%. Higher molar ratio of Ce3+ could promote the adsorption of active oxygen on the catalyst surface, which is beneficial to the adsorption of activated reactants or intermediate substances [31,32]. By using Raman spectroscopy combined with theoretical calculation, Choi et al. found that the increase of Ce ions was related to the generation of oxygen vacancy, and found that more Ce3+ was more conducive to the increase of oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst surface [33]. At the same time, Ce ion was a weak Lewis acid species, indicating that the change of adsorption of oxygen also changed the acid-base properties of the catalyst. This could also explain the higher ratio of Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O for the adsorbed oxygen content. Fig. 5(a)(b) shows the CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD analytical profile of Mg3Al1−xCexO and CeO2, and a series of wide desorption band is obtained in the temperature range of 50–800 ℃. According to reports, the CO2-TPD curve of Mg3Al1−xCexO could be divided into three regions, weak basic sites (50–200 ℃), medium basic sites (200–400 ℃), and strong basic sites (> 400 ℃) [32]. It is reported that the weak basic sites are mainly related to the interaction of -OH groups on the surface, medium basic sites and strong basic sites are mainly related to the coordination unsaturated oxygen anion in the catalyst [34,35]. It can be seen that the CeO2 only a faint CO2 resolution peak was found at 164 ℃, and Mg3AlO sample showed three CO2 resolution peaks at 158 ℃, 378 ℃, and 743 ℃. While, with the increase of Ce content, all of the basic site of Mg3Al1−xCexO decreased except for the medium basic site of MgAl0.2Ce0.8O (409 ℃), which is higher than that of Mg3AlO sample (378 ℃). This may be attributed to the excessive involvement of Ce leads to surface agglomeration, indicating that only partial Ce4+ can enter the lattice of Mg3AlO. In addition, compared to the other catalysts, Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O shows a stronger basic site at 616 °C as shown in Fig. 5(a). The reason could be attributed to the partial substitution of Ce4+ for Mg2+/Al3+ generates more Mn+- O2- (M=Ce, Mg or Al) groups and increases the catalyst basicity [36]. This may be attributed to the fact that Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O has the most amount of total basic sites (0.355 mmol·g−1). The desorption peaks of different intensities of basic sites were calculated based on peak fitting and the results are shown in Table 3. Therefore, it is speculated that adding appropriate Ce elements could improve the basicity of the catalyst and promote the strong interaction with the matrix. The NH3-TPD curve of Mg3Al1−xCexO catalyst is shown in Fig. 5(b), and the total number of acid sites is calculated according to the NH3 desorption amount in Table 3. Since NH3 is more easily desorbed on Brønsted acid sites than on Lewis acid sites, the low-temperature region attributes to Brønsted acid and the high-temperature region attributes to Lewis acid [25]. As shown in Fig. 5(b), CeO2 exhibits only a very weak acidic desorption peak, and with the increase of Ce content, the desorption peak of Mg3Al1−xCexO gradually shifted to the strong acid region, and the acidity of the catalyst increased from 0.281 to 0.303 mmol·g−1 in Table 3. The oxidation state of Ce species has a great influence on Lewis acid, and Ce3+ is a weak Lewis acid. The reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ would reduce the acidity [37]. In fact, the Lewis acid site is mainly allocated to the Al3+ cation in the mixed oxide [34,35,37,38]. Due to the low introduction of Ce3+, partial Al3+ in the lattice is replaced, leading to the weakening of the acidity of the catalyst, which is consistent with the results of Ce3+ in XPS. It is crucial to understand the structure-activity relationship of the catalyst, and it can be found that the acid-base properties of Mg3Al1−xCexO shows a strong dependence on the reaction activity ( Fig. 6). Apparently, with more basic sites and suitable acidic sites favoring a more efficient synthesis of ethylene carbonate. Compared to pure CeO2 and Mg3AlO catalysts, which are weaker acidity and basicity, the above results indicate that the interaction between Ce species and Mg3AlO oxides facilitates the improvement of the acidity and basicity of the catalysts. 3.2 Performance of catalyst Parameswaram and song et al. used MgO-CeO2 and CeO2-CdO HT as catalysts in the reaction of glycerol transesterification to synthesis glycerol carbonate, respectively [39,40]. The results showed that the yields of glycerol carbonate could reach 86.0% and 96.0% by adjusting the ratio of CeO2, improving the structure of the catalyst and the number of basic centers on the surface. Therefore, under the same reaction conditions (130 °C, 80 min, 5 wt.%), the catalytic performance of Mg3Al1−xCexO catalysts were tested in the transesterification of ethylene glycol with dimethyl carbonate to produce ethylene carbonate ( Fig. 7). It can be seen that all catalysts showed some catalytic activity in the synthesis of ethylene carbonate, the difference lies in the conversion rate of ethylene glycol. As can be seen in Fig. 7, the pure Mg3AlO catalyst conversion only 23.1% of ethylene glycol, and the catalytic effect is greatly improved when Ce is added. Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O had the best catalytic activity, reaching 94.4% conversion of ethylene glycol within 50 min. Compared with Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O, with the increase of Ce content, the catalytic effect of Mg3Al0.5Ce0.5O and Mg3Al0.2Ce0.8O decreased, and the ethylene glycol conversion was 72.3% and 65.7%, respectively. The results showed that compared to the Mg3AlO catalyst, adding the proper amount of Ce can significantly improve the catalyst's catalytic performance. In conclusion, the Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O catalyst has the best catalytic performance. 3.3 Reaction pathway analysis In order to effectively and accurately identify the consumption of raw materials, the change of intermediates, and the formation trend of products in the reaction system, an automatic reactor with an operando IR spectroscopy probe is used to monitor the reaction process in real-time [41]. Fig. 8 shows the three-dimensional changes under monitoring conditions, and Fig. 8 shows the trend of characteristic peaks of dimethyl carbonate and ethylene carbonate. As shown in Fig. 9 that 1455 cm−1 (deformation vibration of -CH3 on -OCH3) and 1753 cm−1 (CO stretching vibration peak of dimethyl carbonate) are characteristic peaks of DMC [42]. According to literature reports, it is judged that dimethyl carbonate is adsorbed on the M-O ion pair at the basic position in the form of monodentate [43]. Compared with dimethyl carbonate pure spectrum results (CO 1752.8 cm−1), the weak shift of the absorption peak to low frequency is due to the weakening of the bond energy of CO by positively charged metal ions. The formation of polycarbonate stretching vibration characteristic peak V (CO 1743 cm−1) was not found by operando IR spectroscopy, indicating that no obvious byproducts were formed. At the same time, 1154 cm−1 and 1815 cm−1 correspond to the skeletal stretch vibration absorption peak and the unique CO stretching vibration peak of ethylene carbonate, respectively [44,45]. It can be seen that the intensity of the vibrational peaks of all gradually increases with the extension of time and finally tend to the equilibrium value. No significant formation of intermediate products was observed during the operando IR spectroscopy monitoring. Bristow et al. used spectroscopy to confirm the existence of the intermediate product hydroxyethyl methyl carbonate (CH3OCOOCH2CH2OH, abbreviated as HEMC) [46]. Similarly, Knifton et al. proved that the existence of HEMC could be observed only at low temperature and for very short periods of time [47]. No obvious intermediates were found in the three-dimensional monitoring and real-time changes of operando IR spectroscopy. It was speculated that the spectral structure of HEMC was covered by excessive dimethyl carbonate due to the similar structure between HMEC and dimethyl carbonate. In Fig. S2, the characteristic peak of 1279 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of dimethyl carbonate V(O-C-O) with a blue shift during the reaction. This phenomenon is attributed to the induction of the intermediate HEMC by the hydroxyl group, thus confirming the reasonableness of the speculation and proving the presence of HEMC. The proposed reaction path of transesterification of ethylene glycol with dimethyl carbonate to synthesize ethylene carbonate is shown in Fig. 10 [48]. Firstly, ethylene glycol and dimethyl carbonate are adsorbed on the catalyst surface at the same time. The alkoxy anion formed by the interaction of ethylene glycol hydroxyl and the catalyst attacks the carbonyl carbon of nucleophilic dimethyl carbonate, forming an adsorption intermediate (HEMC) on the catalyst surface, and releasing a molecule of methanol at the same time. The HEMC undergoes intramolecular rearrangement on the surface of the catalyst to form ethylene carbonate and release another molecule of methanol. To sum up, it can be found that the catalytic performance of the catalyst depends on the strong interaction between Ce species and Mg-Al oxides. The activity of the catalyst is related to the basicity of the catalyst. The introduction of Ce ions is beneficial to improve the acid-base properties of catalyst. For the Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O catalyst with 2.5%Ce content, under the strong interaction between Ce species and Mg-O/Al-O bond, a large number of coordination unsaturated Ce3+ cations are formed on the surface of the catalyst, which promotes the adsorption of surface oxygen species of the catalyst, which is beneficial to the adsorption of active reactants or intermediates in the reaction process. Moreover, the addition of appropriate Ce species makes Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O possess strong basicity and weakly acidity. Therefore, Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O has good catalytic performance in catalytic transesterification reaction to synthesize of ethyl carbonate. The effects of different reaction conditions on the synthesis of ethyl carbonate from ethylene glycol and dimethyl carbonate were studied. Subsequently, the effects of different temperatures, raw material ratios, catalyst amounts, and reaction times on the synthesis of ethyl carbonate were studied. Firstly, the effect of reaction temperatures from 90 to 170 ℃ on the transesterification of ethylene glycol with dimethyl carbonate was investigated ( Fig. 11). It can be seen that the conversion of ethylene glycol and the selectivity for ethylene carbonate are 52.0% and 98.2%, when the reaction is carried out at 90 °C. With the increase of reaction temperature from 90 to 130 ℃, the conversion of ethylene glycol rapidly increased to 92.8% with the selectivity for ethylene carbonate stabilized at about 98.0%. The reason was that with the increase of reaction temperature, the reaction barrier was gradually reached, and the collision between active sites and reactant molecules was intensified, and the catalytic effect was enhanced. Continuing increasing the temperature to 150 ℃, the reaction almost reached equilibrium, the conversion of ethylene glycol increased slightly to the 95.1%, and selectivity for ethylene carbonate still stabled at 98%. When the temperature is further increased to 170 ℃, the conversion of ethylene glycol is almost 95.3%, and the selectivity for ethylene carbonate decreases rapidly to 89.7% due to the increase of diethylene glycol as a by-product at high temperature. Therefore, 150 ℃ is considered as the optimized reaction temperature. The effect of dimethyl carbonate/ethylene glycol molar ratio (2/1, 3/1, 4/1, 5/1, 6/1) on ethylene carbonate synthesis was studied ( Fig. 12). It was found that the selectivity of ethylene carbonate was stable at about 98.5% when different molar ratios were used in the experiment, indicating that the molar ratio of raw materials did not affect the selectivity of the product. When the molar ratio gradually increased from 2/1–4/1, the conversion of ethylene glycol increased linearly from 79.1% to 96.7%. The reason is that the mass transfer resistance can be reduced with the addition of an excess of dimethyl carbonate or co-solvent, which drives the reaction in the positive direction and increases the yield of ethyl carbonate [49]. However, with the continued increase of dimethyl carbonate/ethylene glycol molar ratio to 6/1, the ethylene glycol conversion rapidly decreased to 88.3%. This is because a large amount of dimethyl carbonate acts as a dilution, decreasing the concentration of the catalyst and reducing the contact between the glycol and the catalyst, leading to a decrease in conversion. Therefore, the molar ratio of 4/1 is the optimum dimethyl carbonate/ethylene glycol molar ratio for the catalytic preparation of ethylene carbonate. Reaction conditions: catalyst dosage = 7 wt.% (based on ethylene glycol), reaction temperature = 150 ℃, reaction time = 50 min The effect of catalyst dosage in the range of 1–9 wt.% on ethylene carbonate synthesis was studied. The results are shown in Fig. 13. Under the stable high selectivity of ethylene carbonate, it was found that the conversion of ethylene glycol increased quickly from 42.1% to 97.1% with catalyst dosage increased from 1 wt.% to 5 wt.%. Further increasing the catalyst dosage to 9 wt.%, the conversion of ethylene glycol was kept almost unchanged. This is because the concentration of active sites per unit volume increases with the increase of catalyst dosage, which accelerates the reaction. Considering the cost of catalyst, 5 wt.% is chosen as the optimum catalyst dosage. Under the optimized conditions, the space-time-yield is 33.4 g·h−1·gcat −1, and the catalytic performance was at the forefront in the transesterification synthesis of cyclic carbonates [39,40,50]. The influence of reaction time range from 20 min to 60 min on the synthesis of ethylene carbonate was studied, and the results are shown in Fig. 14. It can be seen that the selectivity of ethylene carbonate kept at around 97.0%, indicating that the reaction time also has little effect on the selectivity of ethylene carbonate. While the conversion of ethylene glycol changed dramatically with reaction time. As shown in Fig. 14 that, with the extension of reaction time from 20 min to 40 min, the conversion of ethylene glycol quickly increased from 55.9% to 98.1%. It was further found that the conversion rate of ethylene glycol was almost unchanged when the reaction time was extended to 60 min. Therefore, the reaction time of 40 min is optimum for the preparation of ethylene carbonate. 3.4 Kinetics research The study of chemical reaction kinetics could provide theoretical support for the design and operation of industrial reactors in the process of chemical production. Therefore, kinetics study was carried out in this work to calculate the corresponding kinetic parameters such as chemical reaction rate constant ( k ), frequency factor ( A ), and reaction activation energy ( E a ). 3.4.1 Kinetic model Liquid-solid catalytic reactions often involve internal and external diffusion processes. Firstly, to eliminate the effect of external diffusion on the reaction, the effect of stirring speed on the conversion rate of ethylene glycol was investigated, as shown in Fig. S3. The reaction rate of the conversion of ethylene glycol to ethylene carbonate was examined in the range of 100–900 rpm. It was found that in the low speed region (100–500 rpm), the conversion of ethylene glycol increased with increasing stirring speed, and when continued to increase to 900 rpm, the conversion was essentially constant. Thus, the stirring rate used in the reaction (750 rpm) could exclude the effect of external diffusion on the reaction. Further, according to the literature, the effect of internal diffusion on the conversion of ethylene glycol was explored by studying the effect of catalyst particle size on the rate of reaction [12]. The effect of particle size on the conversion was examined in the range of < 180, 180–300, 300–500, 500–700 and 700–1000 µm, as shown in Fig. S4. The conversion of ethylene glycol remained essentially stable when the particle size was less than the range of 300–500 µm, and continued to increase the particle size, the conversion decreased significantly. The powder catalysts used in this work are strictly sieved, with particle sizes much smaller than 300 µm. Therefore, it is considered that the effect of internal diffusion on the reaction is eliminated in this work [51–53]. In summary, the reaction is considered to be completed within the kinetic region, independent of the effect of internal and external diffusion. In addition, the intermediates in this reaction have been proved to exist for a very short time, with a very low concentration [47], and immediately converted to the next step after appearing, so they should not be considered as the speed control step. Therefore, the reaction equation for the catalytic synthesis of ethylene carbonate by reaction of ethylene glycol and dimethyl carbonate can be simplified as Eq. 1: (1) A + B → C + 2 D Where, A, B, C and D represent ethylene glycol, dimethyl carbonate, ethylene carbonate, and methanol, respectively. The total reaction rate equation can be expressed as Eq. 2: (2) − d c A dt = k c A α c B β (3) c A = c A 0 1 − x (4) M = c B 0 / c A 0 Where, k 、 c A / t 、 c A 0 、 c A 0 、 c A 、 c B represents the reaction rate constant, the consumption of reactants per unit time, the initial concentration of dimethyl carbonate, the initial concentration of ethylene glycol, the residual concentration of dimethyl carbonate and the residual concentration of ethylene glycol, respectively. α and β represent the reaction order of dimethyl carbonate and ethylene glycol, and M represents the concentration ratio of dimethyl carbonate to ethylene glycol. Thus, Eq. (2) can be further transformed into Eq. (5), (5) dx dt = k c A 0 α + β − 1 ( 1 − x ) α ( M − x ) β Detailed formulas and calculation results are given in the supporting information. By fitting the equation (S1-S8), it was found that the correlation coefficient R2 > 0.99 of equation (S4) is higher. Therefore, α = 1, β = 1 is the closest to the actual reaction order of transesterification of dimethyl carbonate to ethylene carbonate. The kinetic model is shown in Fig. 15. The slope and intercept represent the positive reaction constant and integral constant, respectively, and the fitted values of R2 at different reaction temperatures are higher than 0.99, which conforms to the irreversible second-order kinetic model. The reaction rate constants at different temperatures are shown in Table S1. It can be seen that the rate constant is positively correlated with the reaction temperature, indicating that an increase in temperature facilitates the activation of the catalyst, overcomes the required reaction energy barrier, and accelerates the reaction in the positive direction. Not only that, it can be found that the addition of appropriate amount of Ce significantly improves the activity of the catalyst in the synthesis of ethylene carbonate by transesterification, so that high yields of ethylene carbonate can be obtained under milder conditions, and we found that the change of temperature has a greater effect on the activity of the catalyst during the examination of the catalyst temperature, which is consistent with the change of the temperature-reaction rate constant. 3.4.2 Activation energy The reaction activation energy is calculated by formula (6), and the results are shown in Fig. 16. (6) k = A exp ( − E a RT ) Where, k is the reaction rate constant, E a is the apparent activation energy, A is the frequency factor, and R is the molar gas constant. When ln k is plotted against 1 / T , the slope and intercept of the linear fitting result are the values of − E a / R and pre-exponential factor. The activation energy of the reaction is calculated as 53.71 kJ·mol−1. Compared with the kinetic results of transesterification reaction of the same type with different in previous reports (Table S2), it can be found that the catalyst used in this work requires lower activation energy for the reaction and has excellent catalytic performance. Noteworthy to say, compared with the 15 wt.% Mg-Al HT catalyst used in the transesterification reaction, the amount of Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O catalyst used in this work was greatly reduced to 5 wt.%, showing higher catalytic performance. 3.5 Long-term stability evaluation of catalyst In industrial chemistry, the long-term stability of non-homogeneous catalysts is an important factor in industrial applications. In order to investigate the long-term performance of the catalysts, the experiments were scaled up and studied under more demanding conditions (high temperature, high feed liquid space-time velocity, etc). The catalyst used in this experiment was not pre-activated and the catalytic activity of the catalyst was studied in a continuous feed fixed-bed. In this part, the reaction conditions of the fixed-bed were optimized, including reaction temperature, feedstock ratio, and feed liquid space-time velocity (Fig. S7-S9). The results showed that under the optimum reaction conditions of reaction temperature 230 ℃, dimethyl carbonate/ethylene glycol molar ratio 14/1, and liquid space-time velocity 3.2 h−1, 93.5% conversion and 95.0% selectivity could be obtained. Furthermore, long-term experiments over Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O in a fixed-bed were conducted under the obtained optimum reaction conditions ( Fig. 17). It is seen that the ethylene carbonate yield was kept at around 89.0%, during in 150 h, indicating the excellent stability of Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O for long-term reaction of dimethyl carbonate with ethylene glycol to synthesize ethylene carbonate. Since the present reaction seldom reported, the catalysts reported in the same and similar reaction paths are compared in Table S2. By comparing various parameters such as product selectivity, catalytic stability as well as recyclability and space-time-yield, it was found that Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O has a lower apparent activation energy among similar catalysts, as well as a higher space-time-yield (41.77 g·h−1·gcat −1) and excellent long-term catalytic stability, making it a heterogeneous catalyst with high potential for development. In order to study the structural and morphological changes of the catalyst, the catalyst was characterized (recorded as Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O-R). The XRD diffraction spectrum is shown in Fig. S10. It can be seen that the phase and microcrystalline size of the catalyst hardly changed after use. This is because the introduction of Ce increases the strength of the M-O bond in Mg-Al oxide and prevents the destruction of catalyst structure [21]. Compared with the fresh catalyst, there was no significant change of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and hysteresis loop type of the Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O-R were found (Fig. S11). Whereas, the specific surface area decreased from 198.6 to 161.9 m2·g−1. In addition, the average pore size peak distribution of the catalyst after use decreased from 5.2 to 3.9 nm, the blockage of the pores by the organics adhering to the catalyst might be the reason for the reduction of the pore size and the specific surface area of the catalyst. XPS result in Fig. S12 and Table S3 showed that, compared with the fresh catalyst, the proportion of Ce3+ on the surface of the used catalyst increased from 17.4% to 54.3%, and the proportion of Oα decreased slightly from 90.2% to 87.3%. Combined with the results of a long period, it can be seen that the adsorption of oxygen on the surface has a significant effect on the catalytic performance. The increase of Ce3+ indicates that when the acidity of the catalyst is too weak, the catalytic performance will be decreased, and only under the appropriate acid-base ratio can the catalytic performance be maintained. The binding energies of lattice oxygen and adsorbed oxygen moved from 529.5 and 530.4 eV to 529.8 and 530.8 eV (Fig. S12), indicating that the electronic environment on the catalyst surface has changed slightly, but the catalytic performance remained stable. This may be due to the residual organic matter on the surface of the catalyst during the use of the catalyst. 3.6 Substrate scope In order to explore the application scope, Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O catalyst was applied in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates using different kinds of diols (1,2-propylene glycol, glycerol, 1,2-butanediol, 1,3-butanediol, 2,3-butanediol) as substrates. As can be seen in Table 4, the conversions of all diols were greater than 99.1%, and the corresponding cyclic carbonate yields ranged from 86.6% to 99.1%. The yield of 1,3-butene carbonate is lower than 90.1% because the ring tension of the six-membered ring hinders the ring formation and the increase of the by-product ether results in a lower yield of the cyclic carbonate [54]. The results showed that the catalytic activity of the Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O catalyst was relatively high in the synthesis of cyclic carbonate by transesterification of dimethyl carbonate with diols. Reaction conditions: molar ratio of dimethyl carbonate/diol = 4:1, catalyst content = 5 wt% (based on diol), reaction temperature = 150 °C, (a) reaction time = 40 min, (b) 60 min 4 Conclusions In this work, a series of composite oxide catalysts (Mg3Al1−xCexO) (x = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 0.8) were prepared by calcining hydrotalcite precursors, and applied to the transesterification of ethylene glycol and dimethyl carbonate to synthesize ethylene carbonate. The relationship between the catalytic activity of the catalysts with different Ce content and the transesterification of ethylene glycol to ethylene carbonate was studied. It was found that Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O had the best catalytic activity in the synthesis of ethylene carbonate. Under the optimized conditions, the ethylene carbonate yield is 98.1%. The structure, morphology, surface chemical state, and reaction process of the catalysts were characterized and analyzed by XRD, BET, SEM, XPS, CO2/NH3-TPD, and operando IR. The results showed that the catalytic activity was closely related to the basicity and adsorbed oxygen content of the catalyst. In the Mg3Al1−xCexO composite oxide catalyst, the strongest interaction between CeO2 and Mg-Al oxides was observed in Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O due to the addition of a small amount of cerium, which was uniformly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst. Due to the strong interaction between Ce species and Mg-Al oxides, more oxygen atoms are absorbed on the surface of the sample, and the higher surface adsorbed oxygen content is conducive to the adsorption of the active reactants or intermediates during the reaction. The presence of Ce3+, which replaces partial Al3+, leads to the reduction of acidic sites, thus weakening the acidity of the catalyst. It was further found that the synergistic effect of more strong basic sites and fewer acid sites was more conducive to improving catalytic performance. After 150 h continuous use in the fixed-bed reactor, the catalyst still showed high catalytic activity and stable catalytic effect, the ethylene glycol conversion and ethylene carbonate yield remained at 93.3% and 89.0%. The operando IR results showed that ethylene glycol and dimethyl carbonate firstly formed HMEC as an intermediate in the reaction, which was rapidly converted to ethylene carbonate after the removal of methanol. The kinetic results show that the ethylene carbonate transesterification reaction conforms to the second-order kinetic model, and the activation energy required for the reaction is 53.71 kJ·mol−1. In a nutshell, from the perspective of the economic feasibility of this reaction route and the sustainable development of methanol recycling, the transesterification of ethylene glycol into ethylene carbonate is a green and feasible route to realize the high-value utilization of chemical products. coredata.dc:description: A series of Mg3Al1−xCexO composite oxide catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation for the transesterification of ethylene glycol to ethylene carbonate. The characterization results revealed that the addition of cerium changed the acid-base properties of the catalyst and that the strong basic sites on the catalyst surface played an important role in the reaction. The Mg3Al0.9Ce0.1O catalyst showed the highest catalytic activity (ethylene carbonate yield 98.1%). Compared with pure Mg-Al oxide, the appropriate addition of Ce was conducive to improving the surface basicity and adsorbed oxygen content of the catalyst. Additionally, the reaction process of the formation of ethylene glycol hydroxyl group with the alkoxy anion formed by the catalyst attacking the carbonyl carbon of nucleophilic dimethyl carbonate to form an adsorption intermediate (HEMC) on the catalyst surface for further intramolecular rearrangement to form ethylene carbonate was confirmed by operando infrared spectroscopy. The reaction kinetics shows that the reaction conforms to the second-order kinetic equation, and the activation energy is 53.71 kJ·mol−1. Catalytic stability in a fixed-bed reactor was studied. After a long cycle of use (150 h), the yield of ethylene carbonate was stabilized at about 89.0%.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient synthesis of ethylene carbonate via transesterification of ethylene glycol with dimethyl carbonate over Mg3Al1−xCexO composite oxide
